results.title: Distinguished guests
results.creator_credit: Louise Meek, Loretta Fisher, AFTRS and P.J. Hogan
results.brief_description: Christopher (Colin Friels) is sure he really likes psychology - but not the way it is taught at his university. Professor Wiseman, his tutor, is a disciple of the eminent European pyschologist, Professor Eisenbach - a cold rational behaviourist whose books are always cited as authorities. As a joke, Christopher and his girlfriend decide that he will impersonate Eisenbach and teach Professor Wiseman a lesson. Co-written by PJ Hogan (Muriel’s Wedding). Also features Tracy Mann.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Louise Meek, Loretta Fisher, AFTRS and P.J. Hogan

results.title: Morris loves Jack
results.brief_description:
Morris loves Jack - or does he?
Jack is a young, dedicated policewoman who lives with Morris, a charming but lazy layabout. But he has become a habit she can’t break and so she puts up with the frustrations and disappointments of living with him - until one night the police are called to a noisy party…Cast includes Kris McQuade, John Hargreaves, Bill Hunter and David Boyd.

results.title: Perception structure or flow (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bob Nichol and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Seeing is believing, and believing is seeing, says this film, in an engaging, involving exanimation of what perception is - what causes one person to see things one way, another person in a totally different way. A film to stimulate discussion, especially in the classroom at senior levels.

results.title: Peoples of the Skeena
results.creator_credit: James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The Getikshan and Tsimshian Indians of northern British Columbia live in two worlds. Against the mountains and forests tower the ancient totem poles; the old graveyards reveal past history; on the reserves the traditional crafts are still practised. But in the school games, in the wedding complete with white veil and white rice, and in the sawmill we see how other ways are being adopted. As climax, the film shows the action-packed rodeo at Kispiox.

results.title: People on Sunday
results.creator_credit: Edgar G. Ulmer, Robert Siodmak and Filmstudio
results.brief_description: This pioneering low-budget film made at the very end of the silent era, was an avant-garde blend of feature and documentary. Its lyrical recording of the streetlife of everyday Berlin owes something to the cycle of ‘city symphony’ films popular in the mid-Twenties. Onto this documentary background is grafted a simple narrative focusing on the interactions between five young Berliners—all played by non-professional actors—who spend a typical Sunday together in and around Berlin. The film launched the careers of all six principal filmmakers involved, and had a huge influence on subsequent film movements including the French New Wave, Italian Neorealist and British Free Cinema movements. This restored version contains important scenes previously missing and features a new score by Elena Kats-Chernin. Written by Billie Wilder, Curt Sidomak and Robert Sidomak. Photography, Eugen Schufftan and Fred Zinnemann. Based on an original story by Curt Siodmak.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Edgar G. Ulmer, Robert Siodmak and Filmstudio

results.title: Distant voices, still lives
results.creator_credit: Terence Davies, Jennifer Howarth, British Film Institute, Channel Four and Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen
results.brief_description: This is the first feature film of Liverpudlian Terence Davies, obviously autobiographical, dealing with a family named Davies and their lives during the 1940s and 1950s. The film is divided into two parts: “Distant voices” (45 mins) centers on the wedding of Eileen, eldest of the three Davies children, and the funeral of her father, events which spark memories of the past, including the frightening war years when the city was bombed frequently. “Still lives” (39 mins), actually filmed two years after the first part, with the same actors but with a substantially different crew. It’s a seamless continuation of the recollections of their domineering and irrational father, played against music and radio programmes of the period to create an evocative and moving picture of family life in the 1940s.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Terence Davies, Jennifer Howarth, British Film Institute, Channel Four and Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen

results.title: People of the rock
results.creator_credit: Clarke Da Prato, Nicholas Balla, Tim Wilson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film follows an Inuit family’s journey to the North Rankin nickel mine. How the hunters became bulldozer and machine operators is explained. Music by Robert Fleming.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Clarke Da Prato, Nicholas Balla, Tim Wilson and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Dispute
results.creator_credit: Fred Moore, Leon Clore and Basic Films
results.brief_description: A study of a typical industrial dispute and the real reason behind it. A personal incident between an operative and a foreman grows, until the whole factory is brought to a stand-still. Concentrates in turn on the operative, the foreman, the shop steward and the factory manager, showing how each of them came to take the attitude he did and how each felt he had no alternative and was unable to withdraw.

results.title: Dishwashing by hand
results.creator_credit: Dale W. Imus, Donald F. Grant and Los Angeles City Health Department
results.brief_description: A film which emphasises the importance of hygienic dish-washing, showing that for health and attractive presentation in either large or small cafeterias, dishes must be scraped, pre-rinsed, washed, rinsed and drained. Both mechanical and hand methods are illustrated.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dale W. Imus, Donald F. Grant and Los Angeles City Health Department
